description: finally, something usable and more or less intuitive at the same time!

Used it to eddit some AI generated images (fix some text, colors, add layers, select portions of the image and move them arround and to different layers) and it worked very well!! Some may find the user interface to be a little unintuative but I think its just perfect. Highly recommended for someone who does not want to spend hours or days learning a more complicated tool.

TL;DR: A simple image edditing software with all the main tools you would need to do some bassic image edditing. Highly recomend.
I had to revert my system using timeshift in order to make my fedora stable again
summary: This program messed up my Fedora33

description: Program is ok, the 1-star spam review about having to restore system following installation is pure BS and i've seen the exact same review under several programs already, hopefully admins do something about it.

I used to use paint.net back when I was on windows. Since moving to linux I've tried various alternatives to fill that gap. Gimp is way to complex total overkill for my needs, krita also to a lesser degree. Pinta was close, but keeps crashing. and kolorpaint - not complex enough !

Lazpaint hits the sweet spot, I dont think it was available with Debian Buster, but since upgrading to bullseye it appeared in the repository. after using it for a few days and editing various files it seems to be stable, and checks all my boxes for being simple, easy to use and learn, but still feature rich (enough). ideal for quick edits. 

Only thing I dont like is the file open dialogs, seems jarringly inconsistent with the KDE file open/close dialogs and it would be nice if there was an option to make it consistent with KDE like you can with libreoffice, but that's a very minor thing.
I use it to to annotate screenshot. It loads fast and is easy to use.

This cross-platform application has all the basic tools that qualify it as a usable, robust image editing application. It's not perfect-none are- and it's bound to have distro desease. That's where Linux users blame an application functioning for problems caused by their distro. There is no setting dialogue because the settings are done through the tools themselves. The code has not been updated in a while, never the less it's very good.
summary: Very robust image editing without too much frill

description: Spent three hours editing a file I saved it and when I came back it hedn't been saved.
Confusing interface and fell over the first time I asked it to do anything.
I've uninstalled the program already.
I couldn't figure out how to get it to open a file. You click on "open" and nothing happens except it brings up a box that won't look for pictures. What good is this thing?
The sad moment when you realize that a 1995 ms paint has a better workflow than a program with 10 times as many features but none of them optimized in details.
Ubuntu software should warn if is Wayland compatible!
summary: Does not display in Wayland (black screen)

description: Ok, so the file-open dialog box doesn't work, but you can atill drag a picture file onto the app. Better than Pinta which crashes if you breath on it.

it sounds like they missed a dependency when packaging htis, and as a result, it complains about dcraw missing.

It is a snap, so installing that system wide does not help. I will file a bug also
summary: Bug makes it unusable- will review when working

description:
I installed this because the description said it could handle dng files. On trying to view such a file, it complains that dcraw is missing. That lack of a dependency in a SNAP makes it unusable for me.

In addition the UI is both confusing and limited.
I tried this app several times afrom various computers and it always gives me error messages

I did install v7.2.2 with search "LazPaint", the "lazpaint" search returns older version 7.1.2 (which I didn't try).

As already many mentioned pretty perfect complexity where you need to make a "document" graphics (technical notes, white paper etc.), in which use the GIMP is overkill and many other cut & paste programs are missing some mid-range manipulation tools or do have only photograph filters.

Positive side is that it seems that I can now also replace the Paint.net on Windows machine (or MacOS, FreeBSD if I would have one) with LazPaint.

Compared to majority of Windows programs the UI design is a bit experimental, but in Linux surroundings it drops to average group.
